questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding JavaScript language?

options.option_text: JavaScript is a low level programming language.
The “const” keyword can be used to declare objects with block level scope.
Int, char are some primitive data types in the JavaScript language.
The JavaScript language supports both the first order and higher orderfunctions.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: A web application must implement token based authentication to make theapplication secure.
The JAMStack approach separates out the frontend from the backend, andthey both can be updated/modified independently without affecting the other.
It is recommended to avoid the usage of verbs in the API data URLs.
The idea behind bringing an API is to implement caching.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis?

options.option_text: A Celery system can only use Redis as the message broker.
A Celery system may consist of a number of batch jobs.
A Celery system needs worker(s) to execute tasks.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding webhooks and polling?

options.option_text: The term “polling” generally refers to short polling.
Webhooks are used for 1 way communication, unlike web sockets.
In polling, the connection to the server is kept open, until the data is available.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding cookies?

options.option_text: Cookies are stored on the server.
Cookies are stored on the browser.
Browser sends the cookies to the origin server automatically in general.
Client has to include cookies manually with the request, in general.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding OAuth?

options.option_text: It is a protocol to allow access to resources, hosted on a different server, onbehalf of a user.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?
question_texts: Which of the following is true regarding the Closure in JavaScript?

options.option_text: Closure is the state of the outer function.
Closure is the state of a variable.
Closure is a function along with its lexical environment or surrounding state.
Closures are created every time a function is created in JavaScript.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false?

options.option_text: The server sent events is a mechanism for a server to push events, and it mustrequire service workers on the client to function properly.
In general, a webhook is meant to pull message(s) from an application.
The usage of a message broker over “point-to-point” communication makesthe application scalable.
There is no difference between webhooks and short polling.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding Celery and Redis, assuming a task named “send_email” is defined using 2 approaches given below?  Approach 1: send_email.delay() Approach 2: send_email.apply_async(countdown = 10)

options.option_text: The approach 1 will wait for a user input before dispatching the task to thecelery system.
The approach 2 will dispatch the task to the celery system after waiting for 10seconds, and start the execution, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 2 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, butstart the execution after waiting for 10 seconds, assuming a worker is available.
The approach 1 will immediately dispatch the task to the celery system, andstart the execution, assuming a worker is available.

question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are false regarding Vuex and Vue router?

options.option_text: In general, an application should have separate Vuex stores for all thecomponents.
A path defined in the routes array in Vue router can consist of a number ofchildren paths.
The wildcard (*) should be put at the top of the routes array in the Vue router,so that it matches with all the paths, which are not implemented.
A Vuex store must be used with all Vue applications.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding fetch API?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true regarding fetch API?

options.option_text: The credentials property of the Request interface allows the user agent tosend or receive cookies in cross-origin requests.
The value “omit” of “credentials” will force the browser not to send cookies withthe request.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialseven in cross-origin requests.
The value “include” of “credentials” will allow the browser to send credentialsonly for same origin requests.

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?
question_texts: Which of the following statement(s) is/are correct regarding cookies, local storage, and session storage?

options.option_text: The local storage is a browser based persistent storage.
Cookies are preferred over session or local storage, when the data needs to besent with every request.
The cookies can be set from the server as well as using javascript on the client.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** for the exam **"Diploma Level: Modern Application Development 2"**, along with **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships. --- --- ### **1. Core Topics & Concepts** #### **A. JavaScript Fundamentals** 1. **Primitive Data Types**: - JavaScript has **6 primitive types**: `string`, `number`, `boolean`, `null`, `undefined`, `symbol` (and `bigint` in ES2020). - **No `int` or `char`** (unlike Java/C++). (Q2, Option C is false) 2. **Variable Scoping**: - `const`: Block-scoped, cannot be reassigned (but can mutate objects/arrays). - `let`: Block-scoped, can be reassigned. - `var`: Function-scoped, hoisted. (Q2, Option B) 3. **First-Class and Higher-Order Functions**: - **First-class functions**: Treated as variables (can be passed as arguments, returned from functions, assigned to variables). - **Higher-order functions**: Functions that take/return other functions (e.g., `map`, `filter`, `reduce`). - Example: ```javascript const arr = [1, 2, 3]; const squared = arr.map(x => x * x); // Higher-order function ``` (Q2, Option D) 4. **Closures**: - A function + its **lexical environment** (surrounding state). - Created every time a function is defined. - Example: ```javascript function outer() { let x = 10; return function inner() { console.log(x); }; // Closure } ``` (Q8, Options C/D) 5. **Promises and Async/Await**: - **Promise states**: `pending` → `fulfilled` (resolved) or `rejected`. - **Methods**: `.then()`, `.catch()`, `.finally()`. - **Async/Await**: Syntactic sugar for promises. - Example (Q25, Q28, Q29): ```javascript new Promise((resolve, reject) => { if (success) resolve("Done"); else reject("Error"); }) .then(d => console.log(d)) .catch(e => console.log(e)) .finally(() => console.log("Cleanup")); ``` - **Output Prediction**: - `Promise.resolve(8)` → `.then()` logs `8`. - `Promise.reject(0)` → `.catch()` logs `0`. - `.finally()` always executes. 6. **Arrow Functions vs. Regular Functions**: - Arrow functions **do not bind `this`** (lexical scoping). - Regular functions bind `this` to the caller. - Example (Q27): ```javascript const obj = { propA: 20, propB: () => console.log(this.propA) // `this` is global/window }; obj.propB(); // undefined (if `propA` not global) ``` --- #### **B. Web Technologies** 1. **Authentication vs. Authorization**: - **OAuth 2.0**: **Authorization** protocol (delegated access to resources). - Example: "Log in with Google" (Q7, Options A/B). - **Authentication**: Verifies identity (e.g., username/password). - **Tokens**: JWT/OAuth tokens for stateless auth. 2. **Cookies**: - Stored on the **client (browser)** (not server). (Q6, Option B) - Automatically sent to the **origin server** with requests. (Q6, Option C) - **Use cases**: Session management, tracking. 3. **CORS (Cross-Origin Resource Sharing)**: - **Headers**: `Access-Control-Allow-Origin`, `Access-Control-Allow-Credentials`. - **Purpose**: Secure cross-origin requests. (Q11, Option B) - **CSRF (Cross-Site Request Forgery)**: - Attack where unauthorized commands are executed. - **Mitigation**: Anti-CSRF tokens (sent with requests). (Q11, Option D) - **Flask**: Does **not** enforce CSRF protection by default. (Q11, Option A is false) 4. **API Design**: - **RESTful APIs**: - Avoid **verbs** in URLs (use nouns, e.g., `/users` not `/getUsers`). (Q3, Option C) - **Caching**: Not the primary purpose of APIs (Q3, Option D is false). - **JAMStack**: - Decouples **frontend** (static) from **backend** (dynamic). - Allows independent updates. (Q3, Option B) --- #### **C. Asynchronous Communication** 1. **Polling vs. Webhooks vs. WebSockets**: | Mechanism | Description | Direction | Protocol | |-----------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|-----------------|-----------------| | **Polling** | Client repeatedly asks server for updates. | Client → Server | HTTP | | **Short Polling** | Client asks; server responds immediately (no persistent connection). | Client → Server | HTTP | | **Long Polling** | Server holds request until data is available. | Client → Server | HTTP | | **Webhooks** | Server pushes data to client via HTTP **callback URLs**. | Server → Client | HTTP | | **WebSockets** | Full-duplex, persistent connection. | Bidirectional | WS/WSS | - **Webhooks**: One-way (server → client), use HTTP. (Q5, Options A/C) - **Polling**: Client initiates requests (not persistent). (Q5, Option D is false) 2. **Server-Sent Events (SSE)**: - Server pushes events to client over HTTP. - **Does not require Service Workers**. (Q21, Option A is false) 3. **Message Brokers (Redis + Celery)**: - **Celery**: Distributed task queue. - **Components**: - **Broker** (Redis/RabbitMQ): Stores tasks. - **Workers**: Execute tasks. - **Beat**: Scheduler for periodic tasks. - **Task Dispatch**: - `task.delay()`: Immediate execution. - `task.apply_async(countdown=10)`: Delayed execution (10s). (Q22, Option C) - **Redis**: Can be used as a broker **or** cache/database. (Q4, Option A is false) --- #### **D. Vue.js** 1. **Core Concepts**: - **Reactivity**: Data-driven DOM updates. - **Directives**: - `v-model`: Two-way data binding. - `v-for`: Render lists. - `v-if`/`v-show`: Conditional rendering. - `v-bind`: Bind attributes (e.g., `:class`). - `v-on`: Event handling (e.g., `@click`). 2. **Component Lifecycle**: - `mounted()`: Called after DOM insertion (for initial setup). (Q10) 3. **Computed Properties vs. Methods**: - **Computed**: Cached, reactive (use for derived data). - **Methods**: Re-run on every render. 4. **Class/Style Binding**: - **Object Syntax**: ```html
``` - **Array Syntax**: ```html
``` (Q20, Options A/C) 5. **Vue Router**: - **Dynamic Routes**: `/profile/:name` → `this.$route.params.name`. - **Nested Routes**: Children routes under a parent. Example (Q18): ```javascript routes: [ { path: '/', component: Movies, children: [ { path: 'hindi', component: Hindi }, { path: '*', component: Error } // Wildcard (must be last) ] } ] ``` - **Navigation**: `this.$router.push({ name: 'profile', params: { name: 'narendra' } })`. (Q17) 6. **Vuex (State Management)**: - **Store**: Centralized state. - **Mutations**: Synchronous state updates. - **Actions**: Asynchronous operations (commit mutations). - **Getters**: Computed properties for store. - Example (Q26): ```javascript mutations: { updateFinal(state, { minExperience, maxAge }) { state.shortlisted = state.candidates.filter(c => c.experience >= minExperience && c.age < maxAge ); } }, actions: { sendTask({ commit }) { commit('updateFinal', { minExperience: 3, maxAge: 30 }); } } ``` 7. **Props and Custom Events**: - **Parent → Child**: Pass data via `props`. - **Child → Parent**: Emit events (`$emit`). - Example (Q16): ```javascript Vue.component('custom-input', { props: ['value'], template: `` }); ``` 8. **Local Storage**: - Persists across sessions. - Example (Q10): ```javascript mounted() { this.name = localStorage.getItem('name') || 'Default'; }, methods: { doSomething() { localStorage.setItem('name', this.name); } } ``` --- #### **E. Modern Web Architectures** 1. **JAMStack**: - **J**avaScript, **A**PIs, **M**arkup. - Decouples frontend (static) from backend (dynamic). 2. **Web Storage**: | Type | Scope | Persistence | Accessible via JS | Sent with Requests | |-----------------|-------------|-------------|-------------------|--------------------| | **Cookies** | Domain | Configurable| Yes | Yes | | **Local Storage** | Domain | Persistent | Yes | No | | **Session Storage** | Tab | Tab lifetime | Yes | No | (Q33, Option D) --- --- ### **2. Key Equations/Code Snippets** #### **JavaScript** 1. **Promise Chaining**: ```javascript new Promise((resolve, reject) => { let a = 2 * 4 || 0 / 4; // 8 (since 2*4=8 is truthy) let b = 3 * 4 && 0 / 4; // 0 (since 0/4=0 is falsy) if (a > b) resolve(a); // 8 > 0 → resolve(8) else reject(b); }) .then(d => console.log("Passed:", d)) // Passed: 8 .catch(e => console.log("Failed:", e)) .finally(() => console.log("About to finish")); // Always runs ``` (Q25, Output: `Passed: 8` → **Option D is incorrect**; correct output is `Passed: 8` + `About to finish` + `Finished !! undefined`.) 2. **Closure Example**: ```javascript function outer() { let x = 10; return function inner() { console.log(x); }; // Remembers `x` } const innerFunc = outer(); innerFunc(); // 10 ``` 3. **Async/Await**: ```javascript async function fetchData() { const data = await fetch('https://api.example.com'); return data.json(); } ``` #### **Vue.js** 1. **Computed Property**: ```javascript computed: { evenNumbers() { return this.numbers.filter(n => n % 2 === 0); } } ``` 2. **Vuex Mutation**: ```javascript mutations: { addItem(state, item) { state.items.push(item); } } ``` 3. **Dynamic Class Binding**: ```html
``` --- --- ### **3. Mermaid Knowledge Graphs** #### **Graph 1: JavaScript Core Concepts** ```mermaid graph TD A[JavaScript] --> B[Primitive Types] A --> C[Functions] C --> C1[First-Class Functions] C --> C2[Higher-Order Functions] C --> C3[Closures] A --> D[Asynchronous] D --> D1[Promises] D --> D2[Async/Await] D --> D3[Callbacks] A --> E[Scoping] E --> E1[var] E --> E2[let/const] ``` #### **Graph 2: Web Technologies** ```mermaid graph TD A[Web Technologies] --> B[Authentication] B --> B1[OAuth 2.0] B --> B2[JWT] A --> C[HTTP] C --> C1[Cookies] C --> C2[CORS] C --> C3[CSRF] A --> D[APIs] D --> D1[REST] D --> D2[GraphQL] D --> D3[Webhooks] ``` #### **Graph 3: Vue.js Ecosystem** ```mermaid graph TD A[Vue.js] --> B[Core] B --> B1[Reactivity] B --> B2[Directives] B --> B3[Lifecycle Hooks] A --> C[Components] C --> C1[Props] C --> C2[Events] C --> C3[Slots] A --> D[State Management] D --> D1[Vuex] D --> D2[Pinia] A --> E[Routing] E --> E1[Vue Router] E --> E2[Dynamic Routes] ``` #### **Graph 4: Asynchronous Communication** ```mermaid graph TD A[Asynchronous Communication] --> B[Polling] B --> B1[Short Polling] B --> B2[Long Polling] A --> C[Webhooks] A --> D[WebSockets] A --> E[Message Brokers] E --> E1[Celery] E --> E2[Redis] E --> E3[RabbitMQ] ``` #### **Graph 5: Modern Architectures** ```mermaid graph TD A[Modern Architectures] --> B[JAMStack] B --> B1[Static Frontend] B --> B2[APIs] B --> B3[Markup] A --> C[SPA] C --> C1[Vue/React] C --> C2[Client-Side Routing] A --> D[SSR] D --> D1[Next.js] D --> D2[Nuxt.js] ``` --- --- ### **4. Exam Tips** 1. **JavaScript**: - Focus on **closures**, **promises**, **async/await**, and **scope** (`let`/`const`/`var`). - Understand **truthy/falsy** values (e.g., `0`, `""`, `null` are falsy). 2. **Vue.js**: - **Reactivity**: Know how `data`, `computed`, and `methods` differ. - **Vuex**: Mutations (synchronous) vs. Actions (asynchronous). - **Router**: Dynamic routes, nested routes, and navigation guards. 3. **Web Concepts**: - **CORS/CSRF**: Know headers (`Access-Control-Allow-Origin`) and mitigation (anti-CSRF tokens). - **Cookies vs. Local Storage**: Persistence and use cases. 4. **Asynchronous Patterns**: - **Polling vs. Webhooks vs. WebSockets**: Directionality and persistence. - **Celery/Redis**: Task queues and delayed execution. 5. **Code Output Questions**: - **Trace execution step-by-step** (e.g., promises, Vue reactivity). - **Watch for async behavior** (e.g., `.then()` vs. `.finally()`). 6. **Vue Templates**: - `v-for`, `v-if`, `:class` bindings are frequent. - **Computed properties** are cached; **methods** re-run. --- **Good luck!** Master these concepts, and you’ll ace the exam.
